text:
Q: Android Studio: The emulator is already running A:

If "adb kill-server" doesn’t work, try killing the ADB from the System monitor application of Ubuntu:

System monitor → Processes

All processes will be listed here. End ADB from here. It must be at the top of the list.

I figured that is my last option and now i am working on it. Will be back with the results.

Q: How do I set a field with a duplicate name of another field in Mechanize? A:

Here is the signature of set_value() method of HTMLForm class.

set_value(value, name=None, type=None, kind=None,
          id=None, nr=None,by_label=False,
          # by_label is deprecated 
          label=None)

As you can see, you could specify type parameter, useful in this case to select the proper field.

Q: Why do my goroutines see stale or repeated keys when ranging over a map and modifying it at the same time? A:

In most languages, map iterators are implemented to scan the buckets in their storage order, skipping those that don't hold a KV pair. (I haven't checked Go's implementation, but I would be surprised if it were done differently.)

Changing the set of keys (by insertion or deletion) can trigger re-hashing , meaning that some or all KV pairs get moved to different buckets. But an iterator cannot know which KV pairs are affected, as it only records the current bucket index.

Array iterators likewise simply track the index they're up to. This means that inserting elements can cause other elements to be repeated by an iterator, and deleting elements can cause other elements to be missed by an iterator.

Q: How do I set a timeout value for Python's mechanize? A:

Alex is correct: mechanize.urlopen takes a timeout argument. Therefore, just insert a number of seconds in floating point: mechanize.urlopen('http://url/', timeout=30.0).

The background, from the source of mechanize.urlopen:

def urlopen(url, data=None, timeout=_sockettimeout._GLOBAL_DEFAULT_TIMEOUT):
    ...
    return _opener.open(url, data, timeout)

What is mechanize._sockettimeout._GLOBAL_DEFAULT_TIMEOUT you ask? It's just the socket module's setting.

import socket

try:
    _GLOBAL_DEFAULT_TIMEOUT = socket._GLOBAL_DEFAULT_TIMEOUT
except AttributeError:
    _GLOBAL_DEFAULT_TIMEOUT = object()

Q: Create a folder if it doesn't already exist A:

Here is a clean, simple, and reliable solution for creating a folder in PHP only if it doesn’t already exist. This works perfectly for WordPress themes, plugins, or any PHP script.

$upload_dir = WP_CONTENT_DIR . '/uploads';

if ( ! file_exists( $upload_dir ) ) {
    wp_mkdir_p( $upload_dir );
}

Explanation

1. $upload_dir

Constructs the desired folder path (wp-content/uploads).

2. file_exists()

Checks whether the folder already exists.

3. wp_mkdir_p()

WordPress’ safe directory-creation function:

  • Creates the folder recursively

  • Applies proper permissions

  • Works across different hosting environments

This avoids using raw PHP mkdir() and ensures best compatibility with WordPress.

Use WordPress Upload Directory API

If you want the folder based on WP settings (recommended):

$upload = wp_upload_dir();
$path = $upload['basedir'];

if ( ! file_exists( $path ) ) {
    wp_mkdir_p( $path );
}

This ensures the “uploads” folder is created exactly where WordPress expects it (even if a custom upload path is set).

Final Notes

  • Avoid hardcoding paths when using WordPress.

  • Always use wp_mkdir_p() instead of mkdir() for maximum compatibility.

  • You can run this code in your theme’s functions.php or plugin initialization.

Q: How do I set up a bearer token in Postman from an environment variable? A:

I think that this has changed since the time that this question was asked. As this is the updated way that worked for me:

const response = pm.response.json()

pm.environment.set("jwt_token", response.token);

jwt_token - is the name of the variable you want to save it to
